trans-unit.source: Submit Hive Queries to Hadoop clusters in the advanced analytics process | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive Queries to Hadoop clusters in the advanced analytics process | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Process Data from Hive Tables
trans-unit.target: Process Data from Hive Tables

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive Queries to HDInsight Hadoop clusters in the advanced analytics process
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive Queries to HDInsight Hadoop clusters in the advanced analytics process

trans-unit.source: This document describes various ways of submitting Hive queries to Hadoop clusters that are managed by an HDInsight service in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This document describes various ways of submitting Hive queries to Hadoop clusters that are managed by an HDInsight service in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Hive queries can be submitted by using:
trans-unit.target: Hive queries can be submitted by using:

trans-unit.source: the Hadoop Command Line on the headnode of the cluster
trans-unit.target: the Hadoop Command Line on the headnode of the cluster

trans-unit.source: the IPython Notebook
trans-unit.target: the IPython Notebook

trans-unit.source: the Hive Editor
trans-unit.target: the Hive Editor

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell scripts
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell scripts

trans-unit.source: Generic Hive queries that can be used to explore the data or to generate features that use embedded Hive User Defined Functions (UDFs) are provided.
trans-unit.target: Generic Hive queries that can be used to explore the data or to generate features that use embedded Hive User Defined Functions (UDFs) are provided.

trans-unit.source: Examples of queries the specific to [NYC Taxi Trip Data](http://chriswhong.com/open-data/foil_nyc_taxi/) scenarios are also provided in [Github repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts).
trans-unit.target: Examples of queries the specific to [NYC Taxi Trip Data](http://chriswhong.com/open-data/foil_nyc_taxi/) scenarios are also provided in [Github repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts).

trans-unit.source: These queries already have data schema specified and are ready to be submitted to run for this scenario.
trans-unit.target: These queries already have data schema specified and are ready to be submitted to run for this scenario.

trans-unit.source: In the final section, parameters that users can tune to improve the performance of Hive queries are discussed.
trans-unit.target: In the final section, parameters that users can tune to improve the performance of Hive queries are discussed.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This article assumes that you have:
trans-unit.target: This article assumes that you have:

trans-unit.source: created an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: created an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions for this task, see [Create an Azure Storage account](../hdinsight-get-started.md#storage)
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions for this task, see [Create an Azure Storage account](../hdinsight-get-started.md#storage)

trans-unit.source: provisioned an Hadoop cluster with the HDInsight service.
trans-unit.target: provisioned an Hadoop cluster with the HDInsight service.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see [Provision an HDInsight cluster](../hdinsight-get-started.md#provision).
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see [Provision an HDInsight cluster](../hdinsight-get-started.md#provision).

trans-unit.source: the data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.
trans-unit.target: the data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.

trans-unit.source: If it has not, please follow the instructions provided at [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.
trans-unit.target: If it has not, please follow the instructions provided at [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.

trans-unit.source: enabled remote access to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: enabled remote access to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see [Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster](machine-learning-data-science-customize-hadoop-cluster.md#remoteaccess).
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see [Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster](machine-learning-data-science-customize-hadoop-cluster.md#remoteaccess).

trans-unit.source: How to submit Hive queries
trans-unit.target: How to submit Hive queries

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries through Hadoop Command Line in headnode of Hadoop cluster
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries through Hadoop Command Line in headnode of Hadoop cluster

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries with the Hive Editor
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries with the Hive Editor

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries with Azure PowerShell Commands
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries with Azure PowerShell Commands

trans-unit.source: 1. Submit Hive queries through Hadoop Command Line in headnode of Hadoop cluster
trans-unit.target: 1. Submit Hive queries through Hadoop Command Line in headnode of Hadoop cluster

trans-unit.source: If the Hive query is complex, submitting it directly in the head node of the Hadoop cluster typically leads to faster turn around than submitting it with a Hive Editor or Azure PowerShell scripts.
trans-unit.target: If the Hive query is complex, submitting it directly in the head node of the Hadoop cluster typically leads to faster turn around than submitting it with a Hive Editor or Azure PowerShell scripts.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line on the desktop of the head node, and enter command `cd %hive_home%\bin`.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line on the desktop of the head node, and enter command `cd %hive_home%\bin`.

trans-unit.source: Users have three ways to submit Hive queries in the Hadoop Command Line:
trans-unit.target: Users have three ways to submit Hive queries in the Hadoop Command Line:

trans-unit.source: directly
trans-unit.target: directly

trans-unit.source: using .hql files
trans-unit.target: using .hql files

trans-unit.source: with the Hive command console
trans-unit.target: with the Hive command console

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries directly in Hadoop Command Line.
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries directly in Hadoop Command Line.

trans-unit.source: Users can run command like `hive -e "<your hive query>;` to submit simple Hive queries directly in Hadoop Command Line.
trans-unit.target: Users can run command like `hive -e "<your hive query>;` to submit simple Hive queries directly in Hadoop Command Line.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example, where the red box outlines the command that submits the Hive query, and the green box outlines the output from the Hive query.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example, where the red box outlines the command that submits the Hive query, and the green box outlines the output from the Hive query.

trans-unit.source: Create workspace
trans-unit.target: Create workspace

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries in .hql files
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries in .hql files

trans-unit.source: When the Hive query is more complicated and has multiple lines, editing queries in command line or Hive command console is not practical.
trans-unit.target: When the Hive query is more complicated and has multiple lines, editing queries in command line or Hive command console is not practical.

trans-unit.source: An alternative is to use a text editor in the head node of the Hadoop cluster to save the Hive queries in a .hql file in a local directory of the head node.
trans-unit.target: An alternative is to use a text editor in the head node of the Hadoop cluster to save the Hive queries in a .hql file in a local directory of the head node.

trans-unit.source: Then the Hive query in the .hql file can be submitted by using the `-f` argument as follows:
trans-unit.target: Then the Hive query in the .hql file can be submitted by using the `-f` argument as follows:

trans-unit.source: Create workspace
trans-unit.target: Create workspace

trans-unit.source: Suppress progress status screen print of Hive queries
trans-unit.target: Suppress progress status screen print of Hive queries

trans-unit.source: By default, after Hive query is submitted in Hadoop Command Line, the progress of the Map/Reduce job will be printed out on screen.
trans-unit.target: By default, after Hive query is submitted in Hadoop Command Line, the progress of the Map/Reduce job will be printed out on screen.

trans-unit.source: To suppress the screen print of the Map/Reduce job progress, you can use an argument `-S` ("S" in upper case) in the command line as follows:
trans-unit.target: To suppress the screen print of the Map/Reduce job progress, you can use an argument `-S` ("S" in upper case) in the command line as follows:

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries in Hive command console.
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries in Hive command console.

trans-unit.source: Users can also first enter the Hive command console by running command `hive` in Hadoop Command Line, and then submit Hive queries in Hive command console.
trans-unit.target: Users can also first enter the Hive command console by running command `hive` in Hadoop Command Line, and then submit Hive queries in Hive command console.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example.

trans-unit.target: In this example, the two red boxes highlight the commands used to enter the Hive command console, and the Hive query submitted in Hive command console, respectively.

trans-unit.source: The green box highlights the output from the Hive query.
trans-unit.target: The green box highlights the output from the Hive query.

trans-unit.target: Create workspace

trans-unit.source: The previous examples directly output the Hive query results on screen.
trans-unit.target: The previous examples directly output the Hive query results on screen.

trans-unit.source: Users can also write the output to a local file on the head node, or to an Azure blob.
trans-unit.target: Users can also write the output to a local file on the head node, or to an Azure blob.

trans-unit.source: Then, users can use other tools to further analyze the output of Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: Then, users can use other tools to further analyze the output of Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: Output Hive query results to a local file.
trans-unit.target: Output Hive query results to a local file.

trans-unit.source: To output Hive query results to a local directory on the head node, users have to submit the Hive query in the Hadoop Command Line as follows:
trans-unit.target: To output Hive query results to a local directory on the head node, users have to submit the Hive query in the Hadoop Command Line as follows:

trans-unit.target: In the following example, the output of Hive query is written into a file `hivequeryoutput.txt` in directory `C:\apps\temp`.

trans-unit.target: Create workspace

trans-unit.target: Output Hive query results to an Azure blob

trans-unit.source: Users can also output the Hive query results to an Azure blob, within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Users can also output the Hive query results to an Azure blob, within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: The Hive query has to be like this:
trans-unit.target: The Hive query has to be like this:

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the output of Hive query is written to a blob directory `queryoutputdir` within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the output of Hive query is written to a blob directory `queryoutputdir` within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here, you only need to provide the directory name, without the blob name.
trans-unit.target: Here, you only need to provide the directory name, without the blob name.

trans-unit.source: An error will be thrown out if you provide both directory and blob names, such as `wasb:///queryoutputdir/queryoutput.txt`.
trans-unit.target: An error will be thrown out if you provide both directory and blob names, such as `wasb:///queryoutputdir/queryoutput.txt`.

trans-unit.target: Create workspace

trans-unit.source: 2. Submit Hive queries with the Hive Editor
trans-unit.target: 2. Submit Hive queries with the Hive Editor

trans-unit.source: Users can also use Query Console (Hive Editor) by entering the URL in a web browser `https://<Hadoop cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net/Home/HiveEditor` (you will be asked to input the Hadoop cluster credentials to log in),
trans-unit.target: Users can also use Query Console (Hive Editor) by entering the URL in a web browser `https://<Hadoop cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net/Home/HiveEditor` (you will be asked to input the Hadoop cluster credentials to log in),

trans-unit.target: 3. Submit Hive queries with Azure PowerShell Commands

trans-unit.target: Users can also us PowerShell to submit Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: Data Exploration, Feature Engineering and Hive Parameter Tuning
trans-unit.target: Data Exploration, Feature Engineering and Hive Parameter Tuning

trans-unit.source: We describe the following data wrangling tasks in this section using Hive in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters:
trans-unit.target: We describe the following data wrangling tasks in this section using Hive in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters:

trans-unit.source: Data Exploration
trans-unit.target: Data Exploration

trans-unit.source: Feature Generation
trans-unit.target: Feature Generation

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The sample Hive queries assume that the data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The sample Hive queries assume that the data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.

trans-unit.source: If it has not, please follow [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.
trans-unit.target: If it has not, please follow [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.

trans-unit.source: Data Exploration
trans-unit.target: Data Exploration

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample Hive scripts that can be used to explore data in Hive tables.
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample Hive scripts that can be used to explore data in Hive tables.

trans-unit.target: Get the count of observations per day

trans-unit.target: Get the levels in a categorical column

trans-unit.target: Get the number of levels in combination of two categorical columns

trans-unit.target: Get the distribution for numerical columns

trans-unit.source: Feature Generation
trans-unit.target: Feature Generation

trans-unit.source: In this section, we describe ways of generating features using Hive queries:
trans-unit.target: In this section, we describe ways of generating features using Hive queries:

trans-unit.source: Frequency based Feature Generation
trans-unit.target: Frequency based Feature Generation

trans-unit.source: Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification
trans-unit.target: Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification

trans-unit.source: Extract features from Datetime Field
trans-unit.target: Extract features from Datetime Field

trans-unit.source: Extract features from Text Field
trans-unit.target: Extract features from Text Field

trans-unit.source: Calculate distance between GPS coordinates
trans-unit.target: Calculate distance between GPS coordinates

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Once you generate additional features, you can either add them as columns to the existing table or create a new table with the additional features and primary key, which can then be joined with the original table.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Once you generate additional features, you can either add them as columns to the existing table or create a new table with the additional features and primary key, which can then be joined with the original table.

trans-unit.source: Frequency based Feature Generation
trans-unit.target: Frequency based Feature Generation

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, it is valuable to calculate the frequencies of the levels of a categorical variable, or the frequencies of level combinations of multiple categorical variables.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, it is valuable to calculate the frequencies of the levels of a categorical variable, or the frequencies of level combinations of multiple categorical variables.

trans-unit.source: Users can use the following script to calculate the frequencies:
trans-unit.target: Users can use the following script to calculate the frequencies:

trans-unit.source: Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification
trans-unit.target: Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification

trans-unit.source: In binary classification, sometimes we need to convert non-numeric categorical variables into numeric features by replacing the non-numeric levels with numeric risks, since some models might only take numeric features.
trans-unit.target: In binary classification, sometimes we need to convert non-numeric categorical variables into numeric features by replacing the non-numeric levels with numeric risks, since some models might only take numeric features.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we show some generic Hive queries of calculating the risk values (log odds) of a categorical variable.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we show some generic Hive queries of calculating the risk values (log odds) of a categorical variable.

trans-unit.source: In this example, variables `smooth_param1` and `smooth_param2` are set to smooth the risk values calculated from data.
trans-unit.target: In this example, variables `smooth_param1` and `smooth_param2` are set to smooth the risk values calculated from data.

trans-unit.source: Risks are ranged between -Inf and Inf.
trans-unit.target: Risks are ranged between -Inf and Inf.

trans-unit.source: Risks>0 stands for the probability that the target equals 1 is greater than 0.5.
trans-unit.target: Risks>0 stands for the probability that the target equals 1 is greater than 0.5.

trans-unit.source: After the risk table is calculated, users can assign risk values to a table by joining it with the risk table.
trans-unit.target: After the risk table is calculated, users can assign risk values to a table by joining it with the risk table.

trans-unit.source: The Hive joining query has been given in previous section.
trans-unit.target: The Hive joining query has been given in previous section.

trans-unit.source: Extract features from Datetime Fields
trans-unit.target: Extract features from Datetime Fields

trans-unit.source: Hive comes along with a set of UDFs for processing datetime fields.
trans-unit.target: Hive comes along with a set of UDFs for processing datetime fields.

trans-unit.source: In Hive, the default datetime format is 'yyyy-MM-dd 00:00:00' (like '1970-01-01 12:21:32').
trans-unit.target: In Hive, the default datetime format is 'yyyy-MM-dd 00:00:00' (like '1970-01-01 12:21:32').

trans-unit.source: In this section, we show examples of extracting the day of a month, and the month from a datetime field, and examples of converting a datetime string in a format other than the default format to a datetime string in default format.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we show examples of extracting the day of a month, and the month from a datetime field, and examples of converting a datetime string in a format other than the default format to a datetime string in default format.

trans-unit.source: This Hive query assumes that the `<datetime field>` is in the default datetime format.
trans-unit.target: This Hive query assumes that the `<datetime field>` is in the default datetime format.

trans-unit.source: If a datetime field is not in the default format, we need to first convert the datetile field into Unix time stamp, and then convert the Unix time stamp to a datetime string in the default format.
trans-unit.target: If a datetime field is not in the default format, we need to first convert the datetile field into Unix time stamp, and then convert the Unix time stamp to a datetime string in the default format.

trans-unit.source: After the datetime is in default format, users can apply the embedded datetime UDFs to extract features.
trans-unit.target: After the datetime is in default format, users can apply the embedded datetime UDFs to extract features.

trans-unit.source: In this query, if the `<datetime field>` has the pattern like `03/26/2015 12:04:39`, the `'<pattern of the datetime field>'` should be `'MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss'`.
trans-unit.target: In this query, if the `<datetime field>` has the pattern like `03/26/2015 12:04:39`, the `'<pattern of the datetime field>'` should be `'MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss'`.

trans-unit.source: To test it, users can run
trans-unit.target: To test it, users can run

trans-unit.source: In this query, `hivesampletable` comes with all Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters by default when the clusters are provisioned.
trans-unit.target: In this query, `hivesampletable` comes with all Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters by default when the clusters are provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Extract features from Text Fields
trans-unit.target: Extract features from Text Fields

trans-unit.source: Assume that the Hive table has a text field, which is a string of words separated by space, the following query extract the length of the string, and the number of words in the string.
trans-unit.target: Assume that the Hive table has a text field, which is a string of words separated by space, the following query extract the length of the string, and the number of words in the string.

trans-unit.source: Calculate distance between GPS coordinates
trans-unit.target: Calculate distance between GPS coordinates

trans-unit.source: The query given in this section can be directly applied on the NYC Taxi Trip Data.
trans-unit.target: The query given in this section can be directly applied on the NYC Taxi Trip Data.

trans-unit.source: The purpose of this query is to show how to apply the embedded mathematical functions in Hive to generate features.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of this query is to show how to apply the embedded mathematical functions in Hive to generate features.

trans-unit.source: The fields that are used in this query are GPS coordinates of pickup and dropoff locations, named pickup\_longitude, pickup\_latitude, dropoff\_longitude, and dropoff\_latitude.
trans-unit.target: The fields that are used in this query are GPS coordinates of pickup and dropoff locations, named pickup\_longitude, pickup\_latitude, dropoff\_longitude, and dropoff\_latitude.

trans-unit.source: The queries to calculate the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff coordinates are:
trans-unit.target: The queries to calculate the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff coordinates are:

trans-unit.source: The mathematical equations of calculating distance between two GPS coordinates can be found at [here](http://www.movable-type.co.uk/scripts/latlong.html), authored by Peter Lapisu.
trans-unit.target: The mathematical equations of calculating distance between two GPS coordinates can be found at [here](http://www.movable-type.co.uk/scripts/latlong.html), authored by Peter Lapisu.

trans-unit.source: In his Javascript, the function toRad() is just `lat_or_lon*pi/180`, which converts degrees to radians.
trans-unit.target: In his Javascript, the function toRad() is just `lat_or_lon*pi/180`, which converts degrees to radians.

trans-unit.source: Here, `lat_or_lon` is the latitude or longitude.
trans-unit.target: Here, `lat_or_lon` is the latitude or longitude.

trans-unit.source: Since Hive does not provide function `atan2`, but provides function `atan`, the `atan2` function is implemented by `atan` function in the above Hive query, based on its definition in [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atan2).
trans-unit.target: Since Hive does not provide function `atan2`, but provides function `atan`, the `atan2` function is implemented by `atan` function in the above Hive query, based on its definition in [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atan2).

trans-unit.source: Create workspace
trans-unit.target: Create workspace

trans-unit.source: A full list of Hive embedded UDFs can be found [here](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-MathematicalFunctions).
trans-unit.target: A full list of Hive embedded UDFs can be found [here](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+UDF#LanguageManualUDF-MathematicalFunctions).

trans-unit.source: Advanced topics: Tune Hive Parameters to Improve Query Speed
trans-unit.target: Advanced topics: Tune Hive Parameters to Improve Query Speed

trans-unit.source: The default parameter settings of Hive cluster might not be suitable for the Hive queries and the data the queries are processing.
trans-unit.target: The default parameter settings of Hive cluster might not be suitable for the Hive queries and the data the queries are processing.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we discuss some parameters that users can tune so that the performance of Hive queries can be improved.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we discuss some parameters that users can tune so that the performance of Hive queries can be improved.

trans-unit.source: Users need to add the parameter tuning queries before the queries of processing data.
trans-unit.target: Users need to add the parameter tuning queries before the queries of processing data.

trans-unit.source: Java heap space : For queries involving joining large datasets, or processing long records, a typical error is **running out of heap space**.
trans-unit.target: Java heap space : For queries involving joining large datasets, or processing long records, a typical error is **running out of heap space**.

trans-unit.source: This can be tuned by setting parameters `mapreduce.map.java.opts` and `mapreduce.task.io.sort.mb` to desired values.
trans-unit.target: This can be tuned by setting parameters `mapreduce.map.java.opts` and `mapreduce.task.io.sort.mb` to desired values.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example:

trans-unit.source: This parameter allocates 4GB memory to Java heap space and also makes sorting more efficient by allocating more memory for it.
trans-unit.target: This parameter allocates 4GB memory to Java heap space and also makes sorting more efficient by allocating more memory for it.

trans-unit.source: It is a good idea to play with it if there are any job failure errors related to heap space.
trans-unit.target: It is a good idea to play with it if there are any job failure errors related to heap space.

trans-unit.source: DFS block size : This parameter sets the smallest unit of data that the file system stores.
trans-unit.target: DFS block size : This parameter sets the smallest unit of data that the file system stores.

trans-unit.source: As an example, if the DFS block size is 128MB, then any data of size less than and up to 128MB is stored in a single block, while data that is larger than 128MB is allotted extra blocks.
trans-unit.target: As an example, if the DFS block size is 128MB, then any data of size less than and up to 128MB is stored in a single block, while data that is larger than 128MB is allotted extra blocks.

trans-unit.source: Choosing a very small block size causes large overheads in Hadoop since the name node has to process many more requests to find the relevant block pertaining to the file.
trans-unit.target: Choosing a very small block size causes large overheads in Hadoop since the name node has to process many more requests to find the relevant block pertaining to the file.

trans-unit.source: A recommended setting when dealing with gigabytes (or larger) data is :
trans-unit.target: A recommended setting when dealing with gigabytes (or larger) data is :

trans-unit.source: Optimizing join operation in Hive : While join operations in the map/reduce framework typically take place in the reduce phase, some times, enormous gains can be achieved by scheduling joins in the map phase (also called "mapjoins").
trans-unit.target: Optimizing join operation in Hive : While join operations in the map/reduce framework typically take place in the reduce phase, some times, enormous gains can be achieved by scheduling joins in the map phase (also called "mapjoins").

trans-unit.source: To direct Hive to do this whenever possible, we can set :
trans-unit.target: To direct Hive to do this whenever possible, we can set :

trans-unit.source: Specifying the number of mappers to Hive : While Hadoop allows the user to set the number of reducers, the number of mappers may typically not be set by the user.
trans-unit.target: Specifying the number of mappers to Hive : While Hadoop allows the user to set the number of reducers, the number of mappers may typically not be set by the user.

trans-unit.source: A trick that allows some degree of control on this number is to choose the hadoop variables, mapred.min.split.size and mapred.max.split.size.
trans-unit.target: A trick that allows some degree of control on this number is to choose the hadoop variables, mapred.min.split.size and mapred.max.split.size.

trans-unit.source: The size of each map task is determined by :
trans-unit.target: The size of each map task is determined by :

trans-unit.source: Typically, the default value of mapred.min.split.size is 0, that of mapred.max.split.size is Long.MAX and that of dfs.block.size is 64MB.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the default value of mapred.min.split.size is 0, that of mapred.max.split.size is Long.MAX and that of dfs.block.size is 64MB.

trans-unit.source: As we can see, given the data size, tuning these parameters by "setting" them allows us to tune the number of mappers used.
trans-unit.target: As we can see, given the data size, tuning these parameters by "setting" them allows us to tune the number of mappers used.

trans-unit.source: A few other more advanced options for optimizing Hive performance are mentioned below.
trans-unit.target: A few other more advanced options for optimizing Hive performance are mentioned below.

trans-unit.source: These allow for the setting of memory allocated to map and reduce tasks, and can be useful in tweaking performance.
trans-unit.target: These allow for the setting of memory allocated to map and reduce tasks, and can be useful in tweaking performance.

trans-unit.source: Please keep in mind that the `mapreduce.reduce.memory.mb` cannot be greater than the physical memory size of each worker node in the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Please keep in mind that the `mapreduce.reduce.memory.mb` cannot be greater than the physical memory size of each worker node in the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
